Introduction

Von Hippel-Lindau disease (VHL) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple benign and/or malignant tumors throughout the body.

Pathophysiology

The VHL gene encodes a protein that inhibits the activity of hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs), which are involved in oxygen sensing and angiogenesis (

figure 1
).  VHL mutations lead to constitutive activation of these proteins, resulting in overexpression of multiple angiogenic growth factors (eg, VEG-F, PDG-F) and increased erythropoietin levels that stimulate abnormal growth of blood vessels and the formation of tumors and cysts in various organs.

Genetics

VHL is an autosomal dominant syndrome resulting from germline mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3.

Pathology

Histopathological examination of VHL-related tumors typically reveals features consistent with their tissue of origin.  For example, renal cell carcinomas associated with VHL often exhibit clear cell morphology (

image 1
), while hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system are characterized by highly vascularized stromal components (
image 2
).

Epidemiology

VHL can present at any age but most commonly manifests during early adulthood.  However, presentation can vary by tumor type, with hemangioblastomas and pheochromocytomas in adolescence and early adulthood (eg, teens and 20s) and renal cell carcinomas in later adult years (eg, after 20s).

Clinical presentation

The clinical presentation of VHL varies depending on the location and size of the tumors and cysts.  Common tumor types in patients with VHL include:

  • Central nervous system (CNS) hemangioblastomas (
    image 3
    ):  are the most common lesions in VHL, usually presenting in the early 20s.  They are considered benign but are heavily vascular tumors that can hemorrhage and cause mass effect (eg, herniation, obstructive hydrocephalus).  They often occur in the cerebellum and spinal cord and have a classic cystic nodular radiographic appearance.  Patients with VHL often present with multiple CNS hemangioblastomas.
  • Retinal hemangioblastomas:  can be the initial neoplasm in patients with VHL, sometimes presenting in childhood.  They occur in the majority of those with VHL.  Although the tumors are noninvasive, they can cause decreased visual acuity due to edema and/or distortion of the retina.  Bleeding from the tumor can also lead to retinal detachment, glaucoma, and vision loss.
  • Renal cell carcinomas (
    image 4
    ):  clear cell carcinomas that are often multifocal and bilateral, occur in up to two-thirds of patients, and develop at a younger age than sporadic disease.  Patients are often asymptomatic but can present with hematuria, flank pain, or a palpable abdominal mass.  They may also demonstrate polycythemia (from ectopic erythropoietin production), hypertension (from ectopic renin production), and hypercalcemia (from ectopic parathyroid hormone-related peptide production).  Renal cell carcinomas are often preceded by the formation of multiple renal cysts and are considered a premalignant condition.
  • Pheochromocytoma:  is a tumor that arises from the adrenal medulla and can produce catecholamines.  Patients may have hypertension, tachycardia, and sweating due to sympathetic overactivity; however, many are asymptomatic.
  • Other tumors include pancreatic cysts, often asymptomatic and found incidentally; rarely, they may present with abdominal pain or biliary obstruction.  Endolymphatic sac tumors of the middle ear are vascular tumors that arise along the temporal bone and can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, or vertigo.

Patients with VHL can have any of these tumors or cysts.  The most common presentation is patients in their 20s with CNS or retinal hemangioblastoma.

Diagnosis

The diagnosis of VHL should be suspected in patients with a family history and classic tumor types, which can be discovered with various modalities:

  • MRI brain and spinal cord with contrast:  CNS hemangioblastomas
  • Dilated fundoscopic examination:  retinal hemangioblastomas
  • CT abdomen with contrast:  renal cell carcinomas
  • Plasma and urinary catecholamines and metanephrines:  pheochromocytomas

Patients with suspected disease should have confirmation with genetic testing for germline VHL mutations.

Differential diagnosis

The differential diagnosis of VHL includes other genetic syndromes associated with multiple tumors:

  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome:  an autosomal dominant disorder associated with alterations of the tumor protein p53 gene.  It usually results in early onset of malignancies such as sarcomas, breast cancer, and adrenal carcinomas.  CNS disease is characterized by gliomas and medulloblastomas, not hemangioblastomas.
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease:  also manifests as CNS and renal disease.  However, the CNS disease is largely due to aneurysms rather than tumors; the renal disease is characterized by progressive parenchymal obliteration by cysts, which commonly leads to flank pain and hematuria.
  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2:  can present with pheochromocytoma as well as medullary thyroid carcinoma.  Eye findings can include conjunctival or corneal neuromas, not retinal hemangioblastomas.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1):  an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by CNS disease and eye findings.  However, the CNS tumor is usually an optic nerve glioma and the eye findings are Lisch nodules, which are pigmented nodules of the iris.  Patients with NF1 may also have cafÃ© au lait spots (hyperpigmented cutaneous macules).
  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2):  an autosomal dominant disorder with marked CNS and ophthalmologic features.  However, it is more commonly characterized by schwannomas, particularly of the vestibular nerve, and meningiomas.  Cataracts and retinal hamartomas are common ophthalmic manifestations.
  • Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC):  a multisystem disorder caused by mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes, leading to the development of benign tumors in the brain, kidneys, and heart.  Both VHL and TSC can manifest with renal tumors.  The presence of characteristic skin lesions (eg, facial angiofibromas, hypomelanotic macules, and shagreen patches) and cortical tubers in the brain (rather than hemangioblastomas) can help differentiate TSC from VHL.

Management

Management of VHL typically involves a multidisciplinary approach aimed at surveillance, symptomatic management, and surgical intervention when indicated.

Regular screening for VHL-related tumors, including central nervous system hemangioblastomas, retinal hemangioblastoma, renal cell carcinomas, and pheochromocytoma is essential for early detection and treatment.  Surgical resection, embolization, and ablative therapies may help manage symptomatic or enlarging lesions.  Laser therapy is the preferred treatment for retinal hemangioblastomas.

In addition, first-degree relatives of patients with VHL also typically undergo regular screening for tumors.

Prognosis

The prognosis of VHL varies depending on the extent and aggressiveness of the associated tumors.  Appropriate management and surveillance can reduce morbidity and mortality, but the risk of tumor recurrence and metastasis remains a concern.

Summary

VHL is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the VHL gene on chromosome 3 (
